Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to organize a workshop to address the question of how Cloud Computing is impacting, and potentially disrupting, academic research computing on campuses all across the nation. The workshop will bring together campus researchers, Chief Information Officers, Chief Research Officers, Chief Science Officers, Chief Information Security Officers, and Chief Financial Officers from campuses all across the country to discuss this important question. Through exploration of the evolving nature of academic research computing over time, the workshop will explore topics and challenges in academic research computing in a variety of contexts, including applications, support, data movement, administrative, legal, and financial.

The outcome of the workshop will be a set of white papers which will inform the compilation of a final report. This final report will elucidate key issues and recommendations surrounding Cloud Computing and its research implications, while presenting recommendations on how this activity could be supported by funding agencies moving forward.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cloud computing is in the early stages of becoming a disruptive force in the area of academic research computing, with questions about how this new method will impact the business and operating model for academic research computing. In 2016, Internet2 hosted a workshop with NSF support to bring together thought leaders from academia – including researchers, CROs, CIOs, government, and the private sector to discuss key issues surrounding the future of cloud computing’s impact on computing in the research community. The workshop organizers sought a broad array of cloud computing use cases, providers, and research groups to best chart the future of this important evolution. Cloud-based computing on campuses is evolving at an increasingly rapid pace, and the goal of this workshop was to explore how the advent of cloud technologies will impact researchers on campuses.

Academic researchers and their host institutions are facing a growing complexity of options for accessing and provisioning computational and data handling resources. This rapidly changing environment presented several key motivations for this workshop, including increasing availability of commercial and non-commercial cloud services that are appropriate for cloud computing in the context of academic research. Through exploration of the evolving nature of academic research computing over time, the workshop explored topics and challenges for academic research cloud computing in a variety of contexts – including applications, support, data movement, administrative, legal, and financial. The workshop was invitation-only to key stakeholders and those who were able to contribute to this final report detailing key issues and recommendations moving forward. The workshop also produced a separate white paper of detailed findings and recommendations regarding the future of cloud for academic research computing as a deliverable for this project.

The workshop included 32 attendees from 24 institutions and 13 states, including representatives from major research universities, corporate entities, a national laboratory, non-profit network organizations, and a federal agency. The workshop addressed topics and challenges for academic research cloud computing including applications, support, data movement, and administrative, legal, and financial issues. The agenda included “lightning talks” on cloud computing for research; an overview of current knowledge; discussion regarding current barriers and issues regarding the move to cloud; breakout sessions addressing applications/software, research community support/engagement, and data movement/handling; discussion of administrative, financial, and legal issues; discussions regarding the future of cloud and its role in future federal funding; and drafting of the project’s formal white paper deliverable by the group.

The workshop was informed by other reports and working groups that preceded this meeting (including the 2011 Magellan report), as well as current cloud resources available through researchers through XSEDE.  During the workshop, several key applications used by research disciplines were identified as cloud-ready and participants addressed challenges and opportunities associated with wide scale adoption of cloud resources, including those addressed by campuses depending almost on cloud (rather than university) resources to support research. Discussion also included technological readiness and deployment, as well as administrative, financial, and legal issues in cloud. Participants agreed that there was a difference between technology being ready and disciplines being ready, acknowledgement of varying willingness of students and faculty to experiment, and the need for investment in workforce training to meet the growing need for a prepared workforce.  The workshop’s white paper included a number of key findings, including the need for: support of cloud-based academic research computing; the right support staff for successful adoption; an ongoing forum to exchange information; developing shared training pilots among campuses; a well-documented and centralized service catalogue of currently available and federally funded cloud program; documentation and testing of interoperability issues; analyzing various business models across campuses and research groups; definition of best practices for data movement, handling, and provenance to guide collaboration and data sharing; follow-on meetings for smaller institutions considering potential cloud adoption; and monitoring of NIH pilot initiatives to determine potential applicability to other disciplines.
